projects.name: Upcycle House

project_type.description: Denmark's first full-scale upcycled building - demonstrating 86% material reuse at market price

circular_features.description: Two 40-foot shipping containers form the primary structural frame, prefabricated and externally insulated to avoid thermal bridges
circular_features.processing: Containers isolated externally with paper insulation and vapor barrier

circular_features.description: Foundation using recycled steel screw piles instead of concrete slab - movable and fully recyclable
circular_features.processing: Steel screw piles enable future relocation without foundation demolition

circular_features.description: Paper insulation from recycled newspapers blown into wall and roof construction
Facade cladding from flattened aluminum beverage cans and Richlite panels (paper waste + bio-resin composite)
circular_features.processing: Aluminum cans flattened; Richlite manufactured from compressed paper waste with bio-resin

circular_features.description: Kitchen floor tiles from compressed champagne cork offcuts - durable and renewable
circular_features.processing: Cork offcuts pressed into floor tiles

circular_features.description: Bathroom floor from recycled glass terrazzo
Interior walls and ceiling from OSB panels (oriented strand board from wood industry waste) - formaldehyde-free
Windows sourced from production overruns and faulty batches - double or triple glazed thermal panes
Thermal mass wall built from water-filled jerry cans for passive temperature regulation
circular_features.processing: Jerry cans filled with water create thermal buffer wall

circular_features.description: Foundation insulation from Technopor/granulated foam waste (e.g., packaging, ice rinks)

cost_savings.comparison: Built at market price for standard typehus (~13,000 DKK/m²)

build_nothing_new.notes: New build, no existing structure preserved

build_for_longterm.notes: Screw pile foundation enables relocation; modular container structure

build_efficiently.notes: Prefab containers minimize waste; compact design

cbc_assessment.notes: Pioneer demonstration project with 10+ years of proven performance

narrative.driver: Realdania sought to prove that drastically reducing embodied carbon in housing could be achieved at standard market prices - challenging the assumption that sustainable building must cost more
narrative.lessons_learned: After 10+ years of occupancy by a private family, the experimental materials have proven durable. Key insight: prefabricated containers and waste-derived materials can match or beat conventional construction on cost while achieving 86% CO2 reduction
challenges: Thermal bridge management with metal container structure
Sourcing consistent quality recycled materials at scale
User behavior impacts energy performance more than technical specifications
Higher design/engineering costs offset by lower material costs

scope_notes.notes: Landmark demonstration project - not public building per se but commissioned by public foundation Realdania to prove concept

data_completeness.upgrade_path: Contact Realdania By & Byg for detailed material tonnage data from original LCA

projects.notes: Denmark's pioneering upcycled building - proved circular construction viable at market prices. Now privately owned and occupied for 10+ years.

projects.name: Circle House

project_type.description: World's first Design for Disassembly social housing - 90% of materials can be disassembled and reused

other_stakeholders.name: GXN Innovation
other_stakeholders.contribution: Design for Disassembly methodology and material passports

circular_features.description: Precast concrete structure using only 6 standardized element types - walls, beams, and floor slabs designed for future disassembly and reuse

quantity.description: 100% of concrete structure designed for disassembly

circular_features.processing: Mechanical bolted connections replace traditional cast-in-place joints; elements can be lifted out individually

circular_features.description: RFID chips embedded in all concrete elements creating digital Material ID (material passports) for future tracking
circular_features.processing: Each element tagged with: chemical composition, physical properties, disassembly instructions, producer data

circular_features.description: Mechanical fastening throughout - screws and brackets replace glue and sealant
circular_features.processing: All facades and interior components use reversible mechanical connections

circular_features.description: Floating/click-lock floors instead of glued - can be taken up intact
circular_features.processing: Floors laid loose or clicked together for easy removal

circular_features.description: Lime mortar used instead of cement mortar - weaker bond allows bricks to be cleaned and reused
circular_features.processing: Lime mortar enables future brick recovery without damage

circular_features.description: All installations (pipes, electrical) in accessible shafts or behind demountable panels - no chasing into walls
circular_features.processing: Services routed through visible/accessible pathways for future modification

cost_savings.comparison: Built at market price for almen bolig (~13,700 DKK/m²). Higher residual value expected at end of life.

build_for_longterm.notes: Pioneering DfD implementation - mechanical connections, RFID tracking, standardized elements

build_efficiently.notes: Only 6 standardized precast element types; prefabrication minimizes waste

build_with_right_materials.notes: New materials designed for future reuse rather than current reuse

cbc_assessment.notes: Paradigm-shifting project - focuses on designing for future disassembly rather than using current waste

narrative.driver: Prove that circular construction can work within the strict cost framework of Danish almen (social) housing - demonstrating that Design for Disassembly adds minimal cost while preserving material value for future generations
narrative.lessons_learned: Key innovation was reducing concrete elements to 6 standardized types - this ensures future buildings can incorporate the elements regardless of architecture. The RFID material passport system creates a digital twin enabling future contractors to know exactly what they're recovering
challenges: Developing new contract forms (partnering) to share DfD risk between parties
Creating legal frameworks for material ownership and liability transfer
Designing mechanical connections that meet structural codes while remaining reversible
Establishing quality assurance for materials intended for multi-generational reuse

scope_notes.notes: Public sector social housing - client Lejerbo is almen bolig organization

sources.name: Circle House Facts (Troldtekt)
sources.notes: Detailed project facts sheet including DfD methodology and material specifications

data_completeness.upgrade_path: Await post-completion LCA and material passport data export

projects.notes: World's first full-scale Design for Disassembly social housing. The project's innovation is in designing for future reuse rather than using current waste - a different but equally valid circular strategy.

projects.name: UN17 Village

project_type.description: Copenhagen's flagship SDG-aligned housing development - integrating all 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals with extensive material reuse

circular_features.description: 1,600+ reused windows - double-glazed glass units from 1960s-70s housing blocks, upgraded with new timber/aluminum frames to meet modern energy requirements
circular_features.processing: Glass units extracted, tested, fitted into new thermally-broken frames

circular_features.description: 500 m³ crushed concrete aggregate from Copenhagen Metro expansion used in new concrete mixes
circular_features.processing: Demolished concrete crushed and graded for use as aggregate in new structural concrete

circular_features.description: FUTURECEM calcined clay cement used throughout - provides 30% lower CO2 than standard Portland cement
circular_features.processing: Calcined clay replaces portion of clinker, reducing embodied carbon

circular_features.description: 35 tonnes recycled steel used in structural elements and reinforcement
Recycled timber in flooring, panels and interior finishes - sourced from Dinesen production offcuts and demolition timber
Recycled aluminum facade panels and window frames - produced from beverage cans and industrial aluminum waste via Lendager's industrial upcycling process

build_with_right_materials.notes: 1600 windows, 500m³ concrete, 35t steel recycled; FUTURECEM low-carbon cement

cbc_assessment.notes: Flagship project demonstrating industrial upcycling at urban scale - 535 units across 5 buildings

narrative.driver: Demonstrate that large-scale urban housing can integrate all 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals while remaining commercially viable - showing investors that sustainability creates value
narrative.lessons_learned: Industrial upcycling at scale requires systematic material sourcing partnerships. The 1,600 windows came from multiple renovation projects coordinated through Lendager UP. Low-carbon cement (FUTURECEM) can be specified at scale with willing suppliers.
challenges: Coordinating multiple material streams from diverse donor sources
Meeting fire regulations in timber/hybrid high-rise (Noli tower)
Balancing DGNB Platinum requirements with circular material use
Certifying reused windows to meet current energy standards

scope_notes.notes: Private developer (NREP) but represents significant commercial proof point for circular construction

data_completeness.upgrade_path: Request full LCA report from NREP; obtain detailed material passport data

projects.notes: Copenhagen's landmark sustainable housing - integrates all 17 SDGs. DGNB Platinum certified with extensive material reuse including 1,600 windows and 500m³ recycled concrete aggregate.

projects.name: Resource Rows

project_type.description: World's first residential project constructed with materials from demolished buildings - pioneering industrial upcycling methodology

other_stakeholders.name: Dinesen
other_stakeholders.contribution: Douglas and oak offcuts from flooring production

circular_features.description: 2,914 m² of brick facade modules (UP Mur) - 1×1m brick sections cut intact from demolished buildings and cast into concrete backing panels

donor_source.name: Carlsberg Breweries (Stødpuden, Matrixbygningen) + schools in Aarhus

circular_features.processing: Brick sections cut with diamond wire, cast into prefab concrete backing panels for installation

cost_comparison.notes: 38% CO2 savings (49 kg CO2-eq/m²); slightly higher initial cost offset by LCC benefits

circular_features.description: Reused windows (UP Vinduer) with 50% reclaimed double-glazed glass from energy renovations, meeting 2020 energy requirements
7 tonnes of timber from multiple sources: Douglas fir offcuts from Dinesen flooring production for facades/floors, Copenhagen Metro railway sleepers for terraces (shou-sugi-ban treated)
circular_features.processing: Metro sleepers heat-treated with shou-sugi-ban method; Dinesen offcuts planed and finished

circular_features.description: Concrete beams from demolished Vox factory in Amager reused as pedestrian bridge across courtyard

co2_reduction.comparison_basis: 50-year LCA vs SBi benchmark (includes embodied + operational)

waste_diverted.description: Building materials upcycled instead of landfilled

cost_savings.comparison: 50-year NPV savings per townhouse vs benchmark (total DKK 3.92M vs 3.98M)

build_for_longterm.notes: Brick modules designed for 50-100 year lifespan; some modularity

build_efficiently.notes: Efficient rowhouse typology; prefab brick modules reduce waste

build_with_right_materials.notes: 10% reuse by weight; strong methodology; 463 tonnes diverted

cbc_assessment.notes: Pioneer project - proved commercial viability of upcycling methodology. Quality multiplier 1.3 due to third-party verified LCA/LCC data.

awards: Featured in Dezeen, ArchDaily, Detail, Bau, Architects Journal

narrative.driver: Prove that industrial-scale upcycling of demolition materials could work commercially - creating a replicable methodology (UP Mur, UP Vinduer, UP Beton) that Lendager could apply to subsequent projects
narrative.lessons_learned: Brick modules (UP Mur) were the breakthrough innovation - cutting 1×1m sections intact preserves the visual character while concrete backing provides structural integrity. Created 18 jobs (0.5 FTE years) through material processing. Same price per m² achieved as conventional construction.
challenges: Developing cutting and mounting methodology for intact brick sections
Certifying reused materials to meet building codes
Coordinating multiple demolition sites for material sourcing
Quality control across heterogeneous material streams

scope_notes.notes: Private developer (NREP) - landmark project that proved industrial upcycling methodology commercially viable

sources.name: NREP LCA/LCC Report - Upcycle Studios & Resource Rows

projects.notes: World's first residential project from demolished building materials. 10% reuse by weight achieved 29% CO2 reduction - proved industrial upcycling methodology commercially viable at same price as conventional.

projects.name: FBAB Seest

project_type.description: Denmark's competition-winning sustainable social housing - FSC timber construction with DGNB Gold certification

circular_features.description: FSC-certified wood construction throughout - wooden support structures and elements with only support pillars in concrete
Wood fiber insulation for thermal performance - natural, renewable material
Heat-treated spruce cladding requiring no further chemical treatment, minimizing maintenance impacts
circular_features.processing: Thermal modification eliminates need for preservatives

circular_features.description: On-site rainwater retention - all rainwater directed to two lakes, natural areas, and basement basins under parking

co2_reduction.comparison_basis: Wood construction vs conventional - significant reduction claimed but not quantified

build_for_longterm.notes: Cluster layout enables community adaptation; timber construction could enable future reconfiguration

build_with_right_materials.notes: FSC wood throughout - significant carbon storage and biobased construction

cbc_assessment.notes: Competition-winning project demonstrating wood construction for social housing at scale

awards: Kolding Municipality Architectural Award 2019 - Innovation and Sustainability category

narrative.driver: Won 2013 national competition by Danish Ministry for Cities, Housing and Rural Districts to demonstrate sustainable social housing concepts at affordable rents
narrative.lessons_learned: FSC timber construction can achieve DGNB Gold while maintaining market-appropriate rents (5,700-9,200 DKK/month). Heat-treated wood eliminates ongoing chemical treatment needs.
challenges: Balancing sustainability goals with social housing cost requirements
Integrating rainwater management within residential development
Achieving thermal performance with wood construction

scope_notes.notes: Public sector social housing - Lejerbo is almen bolig organization

data_completeness.upgrade_path: Request LCA data from Lejerbo or Dissing+Weitling

projects.circularity_qualification: FSC-certified timber construction throughout with DGNB Gold certification - demonstrating low-carbon materials at social housing scale
projects.notes: Competition-winning social housing demonstrating FSC timber construction at market-appropriate rents. Won Kolding Architectural Award 2019. Included in Building Damage Fund's 2020 quality guide.
